thread.title: No. 5 St. Joseph Academy eliminates late mistakes, tops No. 20 Padua, 52-44
thread.title_full: No. 5 St. Joseph Academy eliminates late mistakes, tops No. 20 Padua, 52-44

author: Nathaniel Cline, cleveland.com
title: No. 5 St. Joseph Academy eliminates late mistakes, tops No. 20 Padua, 52-44
text:
Complete Box Score » 
CLEVELAND, Ohio – The Padua girls basketball team put on a strong effort to cut into an 11-point deficit against St. Joseph Academy Wednesday night. 
But senior guard Ellen Vichill's 3-pointer from the top of the key gave the Jaguars the night's key moment, and No. 5 St. Joseph took over for a 52-44 win over the 20th-ranked Bruins. 
“We just had to keep the energy going,” said Vichill. “When we saw it slipping away, I thought we have to get it together, work as a team and make it happen.” 
Check back later for video highlights, and reaction from coaches and players. 
St. Joseph, ranked No. 5 in the cleveland.com Top 25 , led by as much as 16, but turnovers hurt down the stretch. 
“We’ve been really focused on trying to play all four quarters and our word has been ‘poise’,” St. Joseph head coach Maggie Ferrando said. “We ended up coming up with [a win] and finding a way, but we’ve got to eliminate our turnovers at the end, focus on that poise and be smart.” 
Recognizing their three seniors before the game, the Jaguars started the game slowly with a 7-6 lead after the first quarter. The Jaguars began to see more of their shots fall in the second as they forced turnovers during a 17-7 run. 
St. Joseph went into halftime with 24-13 lead. 
Padua exchanged baskets with the Jaguars in the third quarter, trailing 38-28. But in the fourth, the Bruins cut the Jaguars lead down to five with the help of senior guards Alianna Conroy, Elena Rauha and a key 3-pointer by Ali Medaglia. 
With 3:52 left and a 43-38 lead, St. Joseph Academy found the needed poise and was rewarded as Vichill knocked down the key 3-pointer. The Jaguars made free throws the rest of the way. 
“Their fight is outstanding,” Padua coach Dan Brown said about his girls. “Every game we’ve played this year they never given up. That’s a tenacity that will help us to a league and district title, hopefully.” 
Conroy led all scorers with 19 points, including two 3-pointers. Rauhe finished with 12 points. 
Sophomore forward Molly Neitzel’s 13 points paced St. Joseph, followed by junior Bre Coleman (12) and Vichill (12). 
What’s next: 
St. Joseph will host East Tech on Friday with a 5:30 start time. Padua will play for a share of the North Coast League Blue Division title when the Bruins host No. 11 Archbishop Hoban.
